title: Cut off the head....
body:
And I'm sure the playerbase will find other champions to complain about. hehehehehe...

But seriously though I'm posting this because I want to propose a hypothetical experiment, and see what you guys think the outcome would be.

Using the numbers produced from the last week, starting today, every champion with a pick or ban rate higher than 15% will be disabled for the next 3 weeks and the other 80ish% of the champion pool will become free to play for the duration. All other aspects of the game remain unchanged, all that's happening is what's outlined in the title. We're cutting off the metaphorical head just to see how the rest of the body reacts.

Attached is a file, a list of champions that would become and remain playable during the 3 weeks. Everyone not on the list is disabled.

I would to love to hear your thoughts about how this experiment would play out. Do you think the list would remain unchanged for the 3 weeks? Would certain champions rise to, or fall from, power now that other champions are out of the picture? Would the game become more or less fun to play? Will Urgot unironically get picked in a match for once? Would you be interested to see this as a featured (or permanent) gamemode in the future? Should Riot fix Anivia's Q indicator already? Ha Ha. But seriously, care to share your thoughts, anyone?

***EDIT: Added a list of the disabled champions as an attachment.***

He was trash.  The changes to stats made characters overall weaker during levels 6 - 11, increasing the power of early game focused ADC's.  That, along with the Trist nerf, then the more recent changes to her, which hurt her very early strength, made Graves a better pick.  He was always a strong early game ADC with good burst that continued to be strong in the midgame.  Now, though, the early and midgame are longer, and he is the ONLY early game heavy ADC.  You'll notice that the other common pick is Corki, who is also strong in the midgame.  He has some power early, but not nearly as much as Graves, since he has prohibitive mana costs.

At the end of whatever may happen though, a new meta *would* emerge, not because persay the champions being chosen are overpowered yadda yadda, but because League has this fatal flaw where it supports a meta's existence in how the game is set up and played. Until Riot does something, and honestly I don't know what they even could even do at this point, metas will always exist out of what what players believe is "necessity."  I've played this game since official release, and I haven't seen anything in six years that can, or could, refute that fact.

It does *nothing* to solve the real issue. People will just start complaining about the second string after a few weeks.

That leaves very few viable supports.

The reason why so many supports have >15% pick rate is because there's only a handful of *supports* in the game. It's not surprising that when you have 11 supports, many of those will be picked by more than 1 in 13.33 teams.

You eliminate Thresh, Leona, Annie, Morgana, Janna and Blitzcrank and leave Braum, Nami, Taric, Sona and Soraka. Out of the remaining five, the only viable ones are the first two. Nami vs Braum every lane?

Personally, as far as the LCS goes, at least, I don't believe the meta is anything more than teams who lack the courage or the independent thinking to prove that all the champs are viable with sufficient preparation.

I don't think it is a question of courage or independence, it is a question of reliability. Pro players aren't playing League for fun, it is quite literally their job that earns them money. They play what is most guaranteed to get them the highest chance of winning money, just like any pro sports team hires only the best players so that they win most. Only once you get outside of the pro scene does balance really become an issue, because then having people play for fun isn't necessarily about who has the best chance of winning, but who is the most fun to play as.

I understand the reliability issue, which is why pro teams have coaches, analysts, and other support staff to find ways to make comps, and with the recent trend toward Lissandra, Cassiopeia, and Rumble top leaves the team without a dedicated tank, and I don't buy that with all their game knowledge teams can't think of a way to work a Nautilus or Volibear jungle, for example, into the team. it is not even like pure tank is unheard of, with Elise and Nunu being built full tank when they are played. That leaves me with the conclusion, then, that teams don't put in the work to make any of the non-meta picks viable, not that there is any flaw with the picks themselves.

You do have a point about my use of courage and independence, though, as I think the best word to describe them is complacent.

Once again, nobody is understanding the point of this. The point is for you to try new champs, not to complain that yours would be banned or to Get Excited! that your champs are still there to play. After all, this is useless if you just play the same champs that you used to prior and you wouldn't have to deal with any opposing high burst.
